name: Akita
description: A browser extension that gives you insight into your engagement with Web Monetization. Web Monetization is an emerging idea that’s paving the way for a more open, fair and inclusive web, to better support both users and creators. Web Monetization provides a way for micropayments to be streamed anonymously from users to websites.  In May 2020, we learned about Web Monetization. A few keywords stood out to us: open, fair and inclusive. These words weren’t something we were used to seeing amongst monetization on the web, which generally involves targeted ads, paywalls and other unfortunate things.  But we found ourselves struggling to understand and find resources to learn about Web Monetization. To tackle this problem, we began the Akita project. We are creating resources which introduce Web Monetization through storytelling, easy-to-use tools and community outreach.

SDGs.evidenceText: Overall, our goal with Akita is to increase Web Monetization exposure and awareness, and to help people understand how Web Monetization fits in with their regular browsing. We want to give people who aren’t using a Web Monetization provider a way to engage in payment streaming. As more Web Monetization providers pop up, users can choose providers that fit their needs based on the browsing data presented by Akita.
Web Monetization is an exciting new concept! It's paving the way for a more open, fair and inclusive web, to better support both users and creators.

The platform has interactive and adaptive learning modules, giving students access to rich quality digital content and adaptive assessments. name: Book Dash
description: Book Dash is a South African social impact publisher of free books for very young children. Our vision is that “Every child should own a hundred books by the age of five”, before they enter school! Book Dash gather volunteers to create new, African picturebooks that anyone can read, re-use, download, adapt and share.

SDGs.evidenceText: Access to books from a young age (books that are relevant, high-quality, and in mothertongue) is a key component to literacy development. Increasing levels of literacy has been shown on a micro and macro economic level to reduce poverty and inequality.

The WHO's Nurturing Care Framework outline the five components needed for young children and their carers to thrive (rather than merely survive) in health and wellbeing. Access to quality, relatable books in home languages play a vital supportive role in two of those components: Access to early learning opportunities and responsive caregiving. We need to think of early development of the whole child and books play a role in wellbeing and develop socio-emotional skills such as empathy and resilience, as much as they encourage cognitive development.

Increased access to books plays a fundamental role in quality education. Early access is appealing reading materials is linked to reading performance and quality is education is unlocked when a children can read fluently, with comprehension.

Increased access to books plays a fundamental role in providing quality education. Having many books from a young age has been proven to propel children further into education, increase chances of academic and economic success and reduce inequality.

name: Cloudline
description: Providing carbon-free, unmanned aerial services at the frontier in developing markets for humanitarian uses. Our open-source work is focused on expanding the existing open-source software stack in PX4, to include a new vehicle mode, airships. We are also working on providing an open-source refrigerated container for drone delivery at 10kg payload, but are still in the process with the Open Hardware Repository, under a CERN open hardware licence.

SDGs.evidenceText: Cloudline aims to bring affordable logistics access to rural economics that are not connected to regional and global economics. Through outbound services to aid agencies and organizations, Cloudline hopes to enable and facilitate subsidised services to farmers and artisans all over the world. At a time when it costs more than two million dollars to build a kilometre of new paved road, large payload delivery drones allow us to reach communities that do not have the density to make roads viable, with the added benefit of a much smaller environmental footprint.

Cloudline improves patient access to medical products and services, empowers health workers to better serve their communities, and eliminates waste due to expiries and broken cold chains. Cloudline’s airships offer flexible active cold-chain delivery solutions, allowing affordable and timely, cold-chain-guaranteed transport of blood, vaccines, and other sensitive consumables, and collection and delivery of test samples from virtually any location to any other location nation-wide.

Cloudline aims to create new economic opportunities by opening up new markets in rural and hard to reach areas. Our aim is to hire locally, wherever we go. We plan to operate locally and provide all necessary training and up-skilling opportunities (engineering, data science, operations, management etc.) to create economic growth.

Cloudline designs, builds, and operates smart blimps, or autonomous airships. Our airships benefit from combining the lifting power of helium with advanced flight control and power train technologies to offer order-of-magnitude advantages over multi-copter and fixed-wing platforms. Indeed, when compared with UAVs currently being used for logistics, airships are safer (and therefore preferred by regulators), less expensive, more flexible, have a greater range and much greater carrying capacity.  Our South African engineering team is determined to solve core problems at home. The team has been privileged enough to know what seamless logistics looks like in a developed setting, while being close enough to places where that same access is near non-existent. The team brings our multidisciplinary knowledge of mechanical and electronics engineering, as well as Machine Learning, to problems that require expertise on a number of fronts.
Our airships run exclusively on electric power with zero emissions and substitute carbon emitting vehicles.

Cloudline believes in collaboration and partnerships with governments, private agencies and aid agencies towards achieving the UNICEF goals. In demonstration of our commitment towards this SDG goal, we are now in discussions with UNICEF, Red Cross, WFP and Village Reach on programs in Namibia, Philippines, Kenya, Sudan and DRC to deliver diagnostic samples, vaccines and medicines between facilities.

In conjunction with Google Earth, Bing Maps and Google Earth Engine, users can analyze high and very high resolution satellite imagery for a wide variety of purposes, including,  Support multi-phase National Forest Inventories - Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry (LULUCF) assessments - Monitoring agricultural land and urban areas - Validation of existing maps - Collection of spatially explicit socio-economic data - Quantifying deforestation, reforestation and desertification. Its user friendliness and smooth learning curve make it a perfect tool for performing fast, accurate and cost-effective assessments. It is highly customizable for the specific data collection needs and methodologies.

Since its launch, the company has expanded to Baltimore with the Baltimore Water Project.

SDGs.evidenceText: The Detroit water project is aimed toward helping families to donors to pay off their water bills thereby enabling them to focus their attention and funds to improving thee lives of there families without being worried about not getting access to water.

Help can come from anywhere. And people in Detroit need help. In 2014 the City of Detroit was in the middle of the largest municipal bankruptcy in U.S. history and the city aggressively started turning off water to delinquent accounts in a desperate attempt to right the city’s finances. More than 33,000 consumers had their water shut off in 2014 alone. The Detroit water project is a non profit organization that helps to link donors to families that needs to pay off their water utility bills.

description: EPANET is an industry-standard program for modeling the hydraulic and water quality behavior of water distribution system pipe networks. The EPANET Programmer's Toolkit is a library of functions (or API) written in C that allow programmers to customize the use of EPANET's solution engine for their own applications.

SDGs.evidenceText: EPANET is a software application used throughout the world to model water distribution systems. It was developed as a tool for understanding the movement and fate of drinking water constituents within distribution systems, and can be used for many different types of applications in distribution systems analysis. Today, engineers and consultants use EPANET to design and size new water infrastructure, retrofit existing aging infrastructure, optimize operations of tanks and pumps, reduce energy usage, investigate water quality problems, and prepare for emergencies. It can also be used to model contamination threats and evaluate resilience to security threats or natural disasters.

name: Esri 2020 Land Cover
description: Esri 2020 Land Cover Map provides public access to global land use and land cover data with 10 meter resolution.

SDGs.evidenceText: Mapping global agricultural lands, and related land conversion, directly supports work to increase food security. Esri 2020 Land Cover 10m (IO) layer displays a global map of land use/land cover (LULC). The map is derived from ESA Sentinel-2 imagery at 10m resolution. It is a composite of LULC predictions for 10 classes throughout the year in order to generate a representative snapshot of 2020. It includes classifications for crops and flooded vegetation.
Mapped urban areas and trends in urban development can be seen on the LULC map. At 10m scale we can also identify large green spaces in urban areas and agricultural peripheries.

Land cover conversion plays a major role in CO2 emissions (e.g. deforestation and conversion of other natural habitats) as well as climate resilience (mapping forests, mangroves, etc, for nature-based climate solutions).  The LULC map, in combination with climate and carbon models, helps users identify important areas for natural carbon.
The LULC map is directly tied to how we live on land and can map land cover conversion over time.

name: Hyperaudio
description: Hyperaudio is technology that links audio tracks with transcripts.  Having coupled text with the spoken word contained within audio or video to produce an Interactive Transcript we reveal many advantages around the theme of accessibility:  Audio is more easily navigated (each word has associated start time and duration) click on a word to jump directly to that point in the audio.  The spoken word is more easily searched, indexed and discovered.  You can easily share selected parts of the transcript and so the audio.  You can remix pieces of audio and video from the transcript in a non-destructive manner.  Add to this the fact that the spoken word becomes much more accessible to people consuming media in a language which is not their first and that seeing words light up in time to being spoken reinforces learning and helps people with learning difficulties.

name: Liquid Prep

SDGs.evidenceText: Participation is welcomed from software developers, designers, testers, agronomists/agri experts/soil experts, IoT engineers, researchers, students, farmers, and others that can help improve the quality and value of the solution for small farmers around the world

The goal of the project is to help farmers globally farm their crops with the least amount of water by taking advantage of real-time information that can help improve sustainability and build resiliency to climate change.

The goal of the project is to help farmers globally farm their crops with the least amount of water by taking advantage of real-time information that can help improve sustainability and build resiliency to climate change.

Liquid Prep has a developed a great working relationship with partners SmartCone Technologies, Inc., and Central New Mexico Community College. Students in the Deep Dive Coding Internet of Things (IoT) Bootcamp at CNM are designing, developing, and producing a robust IoT sensor and housing it in the shape of a stick that can be inserted into the soil and transfer the soil moisture data to the Liquid Prep mobile app via Bluetooth. The collaboration gives students important real-world experience before they enter the workforce. “SmartCone is honored to be part of this project.  This is a perfect example of technology teams working together to help make the world a better place, “ said Jason Lee, Founder & CEO, SmartCone Technologies Inc.Additionally, Liquid Prep will work together with J&H Nixon Farms, who largely grow soybeans and corn crops on about 2800 acres of agricultural land in Ottawa, Canada. They have offered Liquid Prep the opportunity to pilot test the prototype on several plots of land that have different soil conditions, which in turn can expand the breadth of recommendation options to a larger number of potential users.

name: Open Foris Collect Mobile
description: Open Foris Collect Mobile is a fast, intuitive and flexible data collection tool for field-based surveys. This Android app allows the completion of complex data structures, such as biophysical, socio-economic or biodiversity surveys.

SDGs.evidenceText:
FAO has a long history in supporting countries on national forest monitoring and has developed a suite of open source tools under the Open Foris initiative (http://www.openforis.org/). By January 2021, total of 25 countries have used OF Collect in their National Forest Inventory (NFI) for collecting field data. 
OF Collect has been used in Chad for woodfuel assessment in areas surrounding to the refugee camps, and OF Collect Mobile has been used to gather transaction data and thus to ensure food supply in rural Bangladesh.  In addition, OF tools are used for example for socio-economic inventory in Mongolia and dairy industry survey in Kazakhstan. 
 Of the 50 countries that have submitted a FREL/FRL submission to the UNFCCC, 56% has used OF Collect to collect and manage data from their forest inventory.

name: Open Referral
description: Open Referral develops data standards and open source tools that make it easier to share, find and use information about health, human, and social services.

SDGs.evidenceText: Every community faces a similar challenge: there are many different kinds of health, human, and social services that are available to people in need, yet no one way that information about them is produced and shared. Instead, many organizations collect and structure community resource directory data in different ways — yielding redundant, fragmented silos.  As a result, it’s hard to ‘see’ the safety net. Many people never discover services that could help improve their lives. Service providers spend precious time verifying data rather than helping people. And without access to this information, decision-makers struggle to evaluate community health and program effectiveness. This yields underperforming systems that fail people and communities in tragic ways.

name: OpenMRS Android Client
description: The purpose of this project is to provide an OpenMRS 2.x client for Android devices. The app is designed to cover most of the functionality currently on the web application. The app communicates with OpenMRS instances using REST. It supports working offline (without network connection). The database on the device is encrypted and password protected to secure patient data.

SDGs.evidenceText: As a result of better healthcare information technology, countries where OpenMRS is predominantly used have seen a reduction in AIDS infection rates as well as deaths of both AIDS and malaria. Countries such as Kenya, Nigeria, Mozambique, Haiti, Rwanda, and Uganda have widely adopted OpenMRS as their premier EMR platform or have declared it to be their official EMR. OpenMRS, as an open-source project, provides a unique solution which puts local providers and patients at the center of their health information ecosystem. It allows for low-resource settings, in particular, to benefit from the contributions of others while being able to customize and 'own' their own technologies. This is a foundational transformation that allows for local innovation and the development of new solutions to difficult health-related problems. The OpenMRS community accompanies this work with a model that supports community development, capacity building and local ownership.

name: OSCAR
aliases: Observing Systems Capability Analysis and Review Tool
description: OSCAR is a resource developed by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) in support of Earth Observation applications, studies and global coordination. It contains quantitative user-defined requirements for observation of physical variables in application areas of WMO (i.e. related to weather, water and climate). OSCAR also provides detailed information on all earth observation satellites and instruments, and expert analyses of space-based capabilities. OSCAR/Surface is the World Meteorological Organization's official repository of WMO Integrated Global Observing Systems (WIGOS) metadata for all surface-based observing stations and platforms.

Designed to require no upfront financial investment, a fast learning curve and little time commitment to operate, it is fit for use by communities of developers, modellers, academics up to policy makers.

SDGs.evidenceText: We are aligned with Sustainable Development Goals SDG 3 for Good health and well-being, SDG 5 for Gender equality, SDG 10 for reduced inequalities. Our platform integrates urban and rural healthcare with the objective of meeting the current challenges of lack of resources, infrastructure, trained manpower and specialists in rural areas. In developing countries like India, more than 60 percent of the population is located in rural parts fo the country. Most of the times they have to travel to urban centres, on an average of 50 to 100 kms, to avail of quality healthcare. Upto 70 percent people even pay out of their pockets. This practice makes many drop out of treatments mid-way and even pushes close to 60 - 80 million people into poverty every year due to high healthcare costs. Especially, in the case of women and children, at least 40 percent babies and children lose their lives due to transport to urban tertiary centres. Health workers volunteering in the rural pockets, primary health centres and other rural healthcare service providers and professional are not equipped to handle these issues. Our platform harnesses the potential of artificial intelligence, machine learning and cloud architecture to provide for accessible and affordable quality healthcare to the hinterlands of the country to ensure equitable and universal healthcare to all.

name: Project Sidewalk
description: Project Sidewalk aims to collect open datasets on sidewalk accessibility in cities.

SDGs.evidenceText:
Project Sidewalk seeks to collect open datasets on sidewalk accessibility. This data can be used by city governments to prioritize sidewalk repairs over data collection. Data collected has successfully been used in the past to lobby for more funding for sidewalk repairs. In the future, this data can be used in pedestrian routing applications that take into account different levels of mobility.

These uses for the data we help collect improve the health and well-being of anyone who uses the sidewalks. Furthermore, poor sidewalk infrastructure disproportionately impacts pedestrians that make use of wheelchairs, walkers, and canes. Improvements to the accessibility of sidewalks will help to reduce such inequalities. And finally, our project focuses on the design of accessible infrastructure, so we believe that it fits the Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure goal as well.

name: Safecast
description: Safecast is an international volunteer driven non-profit organization whose goal is to create useful, accessible, and granular environmental data. All Safecast data is published, free of charge, into the public domain under a CC0 designation.

SDGs.evidenceText: By helping people get access to reliable, open data about their environments, Safecast is helping people make educated decisions about their health and well-being.

Safecast’s educational outreach programs and partnerships provide hands-on learning for primary and secondary students to gain skills in engineering and environmental topics that will support future job opportunities and entrepreneurship. Our open and free curriculum ensures that educators have access to affordable and relevant resources.
Safecast’s global volunteer team is reflective of the demographics they serve. We are committed to encouraging and fostering a diverse and inclusive community.

Open platforms build resiliency in both communities that lack government support and infrastructure and those with a high GDP. As leadership and budgets change, open, transparent, community-driven innovation, particularly with regards to measuring the environment and climate change, is essential to the continuity and longevity of a critical system. Safecast’s unbiased open platform is adopted by research institutions around the world and the data is endorsed as reliable and accurate.

Safecast’s openly licensed data platform provides community stakeholders in towns and cities around the world full access to information that they can use to make informed lifestyle choices and influence local policy and legislation.

Air Quality and particulate matter have been identified as significant health factors by the World Health Organization. Safecast is building a network of sensors to monitor PM1.0, PM2.5, PM 10 that is available for anyone to use for free with no licensing restrictions.
Safecast is committed to helping people better understand their environment which is interconnected with the ecosystems we share with other living organisms and nonliving objects.

As an open project, Safecast proudly works with groups across the social and political spectrum and models how to globally scale the dissemination and sharing of information, knowledge, expertise, and technology through open standards.

name: StarHealth
description: An embedded website toolbar and SMS helpline that allows audiences to check whether their doctor is registered and in good standing, whether their hospital/treatment is covered by Kenya’s National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF), and where the nearest specialist health service is for their ailment. Localised versions of the HealthTools also run in South Africa (where it focuses on helping users confirm that their traditional circumcision surgeon is legit, with a hotline for bogus surgeons), and Nigeria (where it includes tools for checking whether users have been overcharged for medicine, plus whether their hospitals are legit/registered) and Tanzania (where it includes gender-based violence helplines).

SDGs.evidenceText: The tools are explicitly focused on providing the public with localised, and in some cases personalised, information on healthcare options to help ensure they take informed decision on health issues, ranging from which doctors and hospitals they use, to whether their medicine/treatment choices are cost effective. The tools also help users report suspected abuse, or danger, to health authorities.

name: SWITCH
description: SWITCH is a power system model, focused on renewables integration. It can identify which generator and transmission projects to build in order to satisfy electricity demand at the lowest cost over a several-year period.

SDGs.evidenceText: This project will substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.
SWITCH makes hourly decisions about how much power to generate from each dispatchable power plant, store at each pumped hydro facility, or transfer along each transmission interconnector.
Access to energy is a basic service to meet basic needs such as safe and healthy cooking and indoor and outdoor lighting in the evening.
Help reduce greenhouse gas emission effect

name: Telemesh
description: An open-source blockchain & mesh enabled messaging application for the unconnected.

SDGs.evidenceText: Telemesh believes that access to connectivity and communication is the key to improve people's lives, social status, and economic development. Access to connectivity directly impacts most of  SDG goals.

Connectivity is an effective medium to promptly deliver economic resources and provide access to the global economy. When people have access to connectivity, it will improve education, health, employment opportunities, and, ultimately, GDP. The Telemesh project aims to connect remote rural populations in an accessible, affordable, and sustainable way. Telemesh can lead to improvements in major socio-economic sectors and lift millions of people out of poverty.

Telemesh Purpose: To solve the significant connectivity problem still exists in this 4th industrial era. Telemesh Motivation: Connectivity has so many essential factors to uplift people's life. The World is dependent on connectivity, and the United Nations has declared it as a Human Right. Telemesh Mission: To bring 3.9 billion unconnected people under connectivity benefits. Telemesh Scope: Infrastructure, maintenance, and data cost are barriers to reach out to those unconnected people. Our solution builds the infrastructure with the handheld device they already have, connect with the data providers as a compliment.

name: The Odin Project
description: The Odin Project's full stack curriculum is free and supported by an open source community. It teaches you how to set up your own environment, and focuses on Ruby, Ruby on Rails, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and NodeJS.

SDGs.evidenceText: The Odin Project is one of those "What I wish I had when I was learning" resources. Not everyone has access to a computer science education or the funds to attend an intensive coding school and neither of those is right for everyone anyway. This project is designed to fill in the gap for people who are trying to hack it on their own but still want a high quality education.

The tool highlights the likelihood of different natural hazards affecting project areas, provides guidance on how to reduce the impact of these hazards, and where to find more information.

name: Translation Initiative for Covid-19
description: Academic and industry partners are collaborating with Translators without Borders to provide machine-readable translation data related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The project has prepared COVID-19 materials for a variety of the world's languages to be used by professional translators and for training state-of-the-art Machine Translation (MT) models. The focus is on making emergency and crisis-related content available in as many languages as possible.

SDGs.evidenceText: The commitments in the Sustainable Development Goals to put the most vulnerable people first and leave no one behind hinge on two-way communication in a multiplicity of languages, yet the SDGs are silent on language issues and many international organizations stop short of listening and communicating in local languages. This project aims to address these issues, contributing directly to achieving goals on good health and well-being (Goal 3) and on social equality (Goal 10). We want to ensure people can access the information about COVID-19 they need and want, regardless of what language they speak. And we are doing so by fostering collaboration between technologists, native speaker communities, humanitarian organizations, content creators, and donors, in line with Goal 17.

description: The Zambia Electronic Perinatal Record System (ZEPRS) is an Electronic Medical Record (EMR) system used by public obstetric clinics and a hospital (the University Teaching Hospital) in Lusaka, Zambia to improve patient care. The University of Alabama Birmingham (UAB) Center for Research in Women's Health (CRWH), RTI, and the Center for Infectious Disease Research in Zambia (CIDRZ) developed ZEPRS with local medical expertise and project engagement from the Lusaka Urban Health District, Central Board of Health and funding support from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
